user.biography: Where great art and courageous conversations are catalysts for a more connected, civic, and empathetic world. We stand with Black Lives Matter.

node.text:
If this past year taught us anything it's that we can accomplish so much more through collaboration with our neighbors and partners. In the final episode of our #YearattheMuseum series, we reconnected with a few of our recent community-based partners @soulsinfocus, @tcahnyc, @f.o.o.dfoundation, and @grandmashandsinc to ask them how we can continue to show up in the years to come.⁠

Video by @as_norskov, Joanne Leonhardt Cassullo Video Fellow, ft. @lavalshante, Director of Marketing and @keonnah, Director of DEIA.⁠

node.title: A Year at the Museum: Community Partnerships

node.text:
So much happens behind-the-scenes of a Museum, and even more so within a conservation lab. Tune in to our latest video with Lisa Bruno, Carol Lee Shen Chief Conservator, for a peek into how we care for our collections—from reversing outdated treatments to stories behind recent projects and what took place when the Museum shut down due to COVID-19. #AYearattheMuseum

Video by @as_norskov, Joanne Leonhardt Cassullo Video Fellow⁠

Treatments featured: William Williams, Deborah Hall (1766) ⇨ Cecily Brown (British, born 1969). Triumph of the Vanities II, 2018. Purchase gift of John and Barbara Vogelstein in honor of Anne Pasternak © artist or artist's estate⁠ ⇨ Assyrian reliefs, Neo-Assyrian Period, reign of Ashur-nasir-pal II, circa 883–859 B.C.E. Funding for the conservation of the Assyrian Reliefs was generously provided through a grant from the @bankofamerica Art Conservation Project.⁠

node.title: A Year at the Museum: Collection Care

node.text:
The role of a curator is a lot more complex than you may think! Hear from Catherine Futter, our Senior Curator of Decorative Arts, on how she accesses the collection and works collaboratively with nearly every department across the Museum. You’ll also get a peek into our new exhibition Design: 1880 to Now, which highlights some of the most important design movements during that period.⁠⠀
⁠⠀
⁠Video by @as_norskov, Joanne Leonhardt Cassullo Video Fellow⁠ ⁠#AYearAtTheMuseum⁠

node.title: A Year at the Museum: ⁠Notes from a Curator⁠

node.text:
What did you miss about museums during shutdown? It's been wonderful to safely welcome visitors back to our galleries, and we thank each and every one of them for taking the time to visit! ⁠
⁠
Now more than ever, the strength of our #BKMMembers community is our greatest asset. We hope you continue your support of the Museum by becoming a Member! We now offer discounted 6-month Memberships—learn more at http://bit.ly/bkmmembers (link in bio).⁠
⁠
Video by @as_norskov, Joanne Leonhardt Cassullo Video Fellow⁠ #ayearatthemuseum

node.title: It’s so good to see you!

node.text: You're tuned in to Screen Time where today Adama Delphine Fawundu (@adamadelphine) discusses “the cleanse” with curator Carmen Hermo (@chermosa). View the video in full on our plaza as part of our Art on the Stoop #SunsetScreenings series, showing each Wednesday, Thursday, and Sunday through November 8, starting at 5pm. ⁠⠀

node.text: Today artist Liz Johnson Artur (@lizjohnsonartur) joins Drew Sawyer (@drewmsawyer), Phillip Leonian and Edith Rosenbaum Leonian Curator of Photography, for a chat about Artur’s work, AfroRussia which is on view as part of our #SunsetScreenings series. We hope you enjoy this brief chat, and are able to check out AfroRussia outside on the Museum plaza through Sunday, October 11. Head to link in bio to find the series' details and schedule.

node.title: Screen Time with Liz Johnson Artur

Head to link in bio to find out more about the series.

node.text:
The Campaign Against Hunger’s (@tcahnyc) mission is to empower our neighbors to live healthier, more productive and self-sufficient lives by increasing access to safe, nutritious food and resources. 60% of the clients they serve are from historically undercounted communities. When you fill out the census, you’re advocating for more federal funding towards organizations like this. Take the time today and complete your census at my2020census.gov. #GetCountedNYC⁠⠀
⁠⠀
And for our community members in need—a friendly reminder that our weekly food distribution with @tcahnyc takes place in our sculpture garden behind the Museum, every Monday at 4pm, on a first-come, first-serve basis. We recommend arriving early to receive a ticket in line. If you have any questions, email us at healthymeals@brooklynmuseum.org.⁠⠀

node.text:
⁠The census determines billions of dollars in funding for our schools, health care, jobs programs, housing, transportation, and so many other vital services. Census numbers in central Brooklyn, Bed-Stuy and Crown Heights are substantially lower than other parts of Brooklyn. We and Council Member Robert E. Cornegy, Jr. (@rcornegyjr) want to change that. Make sure to get counted so we can get a fair share of resources for our community.⁠⠀
⁠⠀
Fill out the Census now through September 30 at my2020census.gov and #GetCountedNYC

node.title: Census 2020: Council Member Robert E. Cornegy, Jr.

node.text:
Live from Studio 54: Night Magic, Marlene Veras of @balmirdance is here to  celebrate the art of the hustle. Veras will first be joined by Willie “MB” Estrada (@williembestrada), first generation hustle dancer and author, to speak about the history of “The Hustle”. Then Veras will show you the moves of this iconic dance popularized at Studio 54.

Apologies for our audio difficulties. We hope you still have fun following the moves!

After learning the steps, be sure to purchase your ticket to see #studio54bkm in person. Our galleries open on September 12! Tap link in bio to book your next visit.⁠

node.text:
COMPANION became the design of KAWS’s first toy in 1999, when he produced his first figure with Japanese toy and streetwear brand Bounty Hunter. The first edition of 500 sold out quickly and cemented KAWS’s place in the public eye. On the difference between toy versus sculpture, @kaws remarked: “To me they involve the same thought process, so it’s funny that when I work big in bronzes, it’s called sculpture, but something I do that’s small and plastic is called a toy.” ⁠
⁠
Plan your #kawsbkm visit via link in bio.⁠
⁠
Installation view, #kawsbkm, Brooklyn Museum, February 26–September 5, 2021. (Photo: Michael Biondo)

node.text: In next week's two-day virtual teacher workshop⁠, learn about the varied ways works of art move from their communities of origin into museum collections. Join us on July 27 and 28 to explore case studies from our Arts of Africa collection and develop teaching strategies that connect objects and their histories of ownership to engage students with issues of cultural exchange and power. Visit link in bio for tickets and to learn more.

node.text:
As we prepare for the grand opening of Christian Dior: Designer of Dreams, please note that our Beaux-Arts Court will be temporarily closed to the public beginning Wednesday, July 21. Our European Art collection will also be temporarily off view and will be moved to our fifth floor galleries in January 2022. ⁠
⁠
Opening September 10, #DiorDesignerofDreams will completely transform our Beaux-Arts Court with a display of over two hundred haute couture garments as well as photographs, archival videos, sketches, vintage perfume elements, accessories, and works from the Museum’s collection. Tickets are on sale now! Visit link in bio for more information.

node.text:
This is the final weekend we’re hosting the virtual exhibition “Straight Lick” in our fourth floor forum. Stop by through this Sunday, July 18 to see 26 “rooms” curated by artist/curator pairs, and supported by a team of registrars, designers, and publishers, all of whom are from Black Art Sessions. For many, @straightlick was the first time showing work or participating in an exhibition in any capacity.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Bakari Akinyele. Capoieristas (1825), 2021. Cotton canvas dyed with natural indigo. Curated by Jenée-Daria Strand ⇨ Attandi. Braid me, 2020. Performance. Curated by Amandine Nana ⇨ Erzulie. Sold Out, 2019. Acrylic on paper. Curated by Adama Dercilia Bari ⇨ ⁠Brianna Perry. Born in the Caul, 2020. Various dyed fabrics, aluminum. Curated by Michele Akinsanya ⇨ Alayna Pernell. ⁠No Longer Peter Cohen’s Property #6, 2020. Archival inkjet print. Curated by Ashleigh Smith ⇨ Kailyn Bryant. SHINE FOR ME, 2020. Oil paint, yarn, glitter, oil pastel, acrylic paint, shredded paper, aluminum tape, and china marker on stretched canvas. Curated by Morgan C. Mitchell ⇨ Abigail Albano-Payton. Path to Resilience, 2021. Oil, collage paper on canvas. Curated by Shannyn Schack ⇨ Alexis Ward. Where Are The Black Designers?, 2020. Watercolor, ink on paper. Curated by Jordan Barrant ⇨ Naomi Soquar. Still from Soul On Fire: A Visual Essay On Identity & the Black Diaspora. Curated by Shelton Boyd-Griffith ⇨ Kikesa Kimbwala DeRobles. You washed me and I was your son, 2020. Acrylic on canvas. Curated by Shameka Jones

node.text:
Forty years after Lorraine O’Grady sauntered into exhibition openings at the New Museum and Just Above Midtown Gallery as Mademoiselle Bourgeoise Noire, O’Grady again debuted her newest persona at the Brooklyn Museum in 2021. This time, in her newest body of work entitled “Announcement of a New Persona (Performances to Come!),” O’Grady is dressed as a knight––posed against a black backdrop, wearing a custom-made steel suit of armor, headdress, and carrying a sword or lance. The artist also trades the public audience for a more intimate practice she calls “performances for the camera.”⁠
⁠
Integral to the Knight’s robust attire is the ability to enshroud immediate recognitions of race, gender, and age. However, through deeper observation, the viewer will notice how the Knight’s presence functions to explore the realms of hybridity––a thematic throughline in O’Grady’s work; European chivalric traditions and Caribbean carnival motifs remain evident in the Knight’s garments of choice. ⁠
⁠
See Announcement of a New Persona in Lorraine O'Grady: Both/And before it closes this Sunday, July 18.⁠
⁠
Announcement Card 3 (Seated Palmate), 2020. From Announcement of a New Persona (Performances to Come!), 2020. Fujiflex print.⁠

node.text:
This week’s #SupportBrooklyn highlights a Crown Heights staple: Cafe con Libros (@cafeconlibros_bk). Keep on reading to learn about the work they do to support their Brooklyn community and beyond. 

“Cafe con Libros (coffee with books) is an intersectional feminist community bookstore and coffee shop. Through our choice of books, programming, and great coffee, we endeavor to create a vibrant community space where everyone—specifically female-identified folx—feel centered, affirmed, and celebrated. Our goal is to widen the network of BIPOC feminist readers, writers, and activist. We need to get clear on an agenda for the world we need to collectively create. The first step is to deeply understand the issues. That most often happens through books and dialoguing in the community. Please consider being an active and loving member of our community!”

Cafe con Libros
Website: cafeconlibrosbk.com
Instagram: @cafeconlibros_bk
Twitter: @cafeconlibrosbk
724 Prospect Place, 
Brooklyn, NY 11216

node.text:
Upon entering our galleries, visitors are greeted by ALONG THE WAY—KAWS’s colossal eighteen-foot-high wood sculpture portraying a pair of gigantic figures with their heads lowered and with one arm around each other in a gentle embrace. The sculpture alludes to familiar childhood toys and cartoon characters while at the same time transforming their identities with a radical shift in scale, presenting them as monumental cultural presences.⁠
⁠
Plan your #kawsbkm visit via link in bio.⁠
⁠
@kaws (American, born 1974). ALONG THE WAY, 2013. Wood. Brooklyn Museum; Gift in honor of Arnold Lehman, 2015.11a– b. © KAWS. (Photo: Michael Biondo)

ICYMI—In partnership with Instagram @design, we’re giving $130,000 in grants to 3 emerging Black designers and 1 Black-led design business in the U.S. ⁠⁠⚡️
⁠⁠
Designers across disciplines—fashion, industrial, jewelry, furniture and graphic designers, to name a few!—and small, Black-owned design businesses are all welcome to apply for the #BlackDesignVisionaries grants. ⁠⁠💫
⁠⁠
Deadline is July 16 so head to link in our bio to learn more and apply! ✨

node.text: Teachers, artists, and activists are invited to join us for  a two-day online workshop on July 13 and 14, where we'll examine how artists use exploratory writing, collage, and archival research to connect their lived experiences to history.⁠ After engaging with works in Lorraine O'Grady and The Slipstream, we'll develop teaching strategies that leverage creative expression to reflect on the fears, joys, and possibilities of contemporary life. Visit link in bio for tickets and to learn more.⁠
